subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Review charts for Shavian Quikscript Extensions
msgSnippet: ... Not in Unicode, where TO uses one set of codes and Shavian/QS use another. -- John Cowan  cowan@ccil.org   http://ccil.org/~cowan The exception proves the
messageBody:
oliver langan scripsit:

> Point taken. I guess my confusion arose when I was thinking that
> Shavian and QuickScript are essentially both English... but in fact
> even mixing TO and QS on a page would be likely to confuse a text-to-
> speech system, to the point of requiring extra markup.

Not in Unicode, where TO uses one set of codes and Shavian/QS use another.

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
"The exception proves the rule." Dimbulbs think: "Your counterexample proves
my theory." Latin students think "'Probat' means 'tests': the exception puts
the rule to the proof." But legal historians know it means "Evidence for an
exception is evidence of the existence of a rule in cases not excepted from."

oliver langan scripsit:

> Point taken.  I guess my confusion arose when I was thinking that  
> Shavian and QuickScript are essentially both English... but in fact  
> even mixing TO and QS on a page would be likely to confuse a text-to- 
> speech system, to the point of requiring extra markup.

Not in Unicode, where TO uses one set of codes and Shavian/QS use another.

-- 
John Cowan  cowan@...   http://ccil.org/~cowan
"The exception proves the rule."  Dimbulbs think: "Your counterexample proves
my theory."  Latin students think "'Probat' means 'tests': the exception puts
the rule to the proof."  But legal historians know it means "Evidence for an
exception is evidence of the existence of a rule in cases not excepted from."
